top_comment.text:
I love when developers use the excuse of architecture. Here is why: because 
most of them use frameworks, and API's and compilers ALL of which deal with 
these "Architectures", some even do memory management for them. I also love 
when they use the excuse that they have to make their games around drivers, 
drivers that use the same API's as they do, using the same exact standards 
to interact with their software.
I know because I do, and I see the API's and frameworks in use and they 
even state what they use most of the time.

In other words making a game is MUCH MUCH easier then they would like you 
to think especially if they are using someone else's engine and code. Not 
saying its not difficult just saying its easier then they would want you to 
think.﻿
top_comment.author: undeadbobop

comments.author: Cynical Aspie

comments.text:
+NewTypeDilemma01 Well, you have to understand that it depends on the 
publisher/developer relationship. 

I find it easier to believe, for example, that an in-house developer, owned 
by, say, Microsoft or Sony, was interfered with by their parent entity. 
Because they aren't independent. They don't get to call their own shots. 
Micromanagement kills great games, and we know the feces rolls downhill. So 
in cases like with Dead Space 2 and 3? Where you can TELL EA stepped in and 
explicitly told Visceral what they had to change to make the sequel more 
profitable? I have no problem blaming the publisher at all. 

That's why I have such a problem with Obsidian fanboys. They seem almost 
anticipatory in their desire to blame the publisher, even though Obsidian 
are independent. They don't have to do anything that they don't want to. 
They don't have to sign any contracts or take any jobs that they don't want 
to. Which means they take responsibility, themselves, for whatever 
successes (and they have those) or failings their titles have. 

The problem is when their fans don't seem to get that memo.
comments.author: The Rageaholic

comments.text:
I realize you're not asking me, but EA. EA ruins everything they touch. 
It's pretty clear they interfere w/ what their devs are doing & HOLY 
FUCKING SHIT has it shown.
comments.author: WhoAteMyFunDip

comments.text:
+The Rageaholic
Okay, I'm probably leaping to the ("stone-dead-fucking") wrong conclusion 
by asking this, but is there ever a point where the blame lies solely on 
the *publisher's* shoulders for you and *not* on the developers? Any 
publisher at all?
comments.author: Cynical Aspie

comments.text:
+NewTypeDilemma01 ...except that Obsidian IS to blame. They had a 
reasonable length of time to shit out a game with 80-90% re-used graphic 
resources and an engine they didn't have to create, they signed the 
contract saying they would deliver it by 'X' date, and as per usual, they 
crawled inside their own ass and convinced themselves they could add a 
billion things that they couldn't possibly ensure would work properly by 
the deadline, assuming that Lucasarts would give them a deadline 
extension... which Lucasarts DOES NOT HAVE TO PROVIDE. Blame Obsidian for 
signing the contract.

Lucasarts isn't to blame for Obsidian not being able to allocate their time 
effectively. Publishers don't HAVE to give deadline extensions. They signed 
a contract to deliver a game by a certain date, so they should have been 
prepared to do just that. It happened on KOTOR 2 (which, for the record, I 
enjoyed. Turn your eyeballs to the KOTOR 2 banner posted on my wall, and 
stop assuming that because I have something bad to say about a game that I 
despise it with a flagrant hatred that banishes all fear) it happened on 
Dungeon Siege 3, it happened on Fallout: New Vegas, and somehow... even 
with 5 years of development, three budget increases, and two deadline 
extensions... it happened on Alpha Protocol, too.

Because Obsidian lacks anything resembling effective leadership.
comments.author: The Rageaholic

comments.text:

Mass Effect 3's "Side Quests" were nothing BUT fetch quests that had a 
miniscule impact on your EMS, there are only 2 variants to these quests: 
Run around the Citadel, talk to this dude, talk to that dude, maybe grab 
this thing, maybe scan something, the end. Or, use your Deus Ex Machina 
probe launcher, need to save people trapped behind enemy lines? Launch a 
probe! Need to find an ancient Prothean artifact that is probably buried in 
some lost city that is uncharted to this day? Launch a probe!

Yeah, Mass Effect 2 might have been linear and somewhat repetitive, but at 
least it was polished and introduced some of the best characters of the 
cast (Who were then mostly reduced to cameo's in a single mission in ME 3.) 
Mass Effect 3 SCREAMS rushed, re-used animations, awful hitboxes, the 
ending, a variety of small things like characters disappearing during 
cutscenes, story arcs that were built up over the past 2 games either 
brought to a sudden disappointing end or simply just not expanded upon at 
all, etc.

comments.text:

becomes so bloated it starts having detrimental effects on the games other 
types of audiences want to play, doesn't it become a 
metaphorical self-inflicted injury in the name of tolerance?  If there was 
balance and there were games made catering for as many different audiences 
as possible, that's fine.  But as we can see the industry is fixated on 
only a handful of demographics.  As a result, I find my tolerance has a 
limit threshold now.

comments.author: Ryan Morton

comments.text:
Heck you could call it the ANTI-AAA game! Wide open areas instead of 
hallways? Health Ups instead of regenerating health? No cover system? No 
Iron Sights? Minimal scripted events with most of the stage just being 
scrambling AI reacting to you? No tutorial? No lengthy cutscenes? 
Lacklustre (but weirdly detailed) graphics but no budget? Buggy and 
unpolished yet delivering a unique experience? and NOT restricting the 
player due to story (like playing a Wing Diver before they're introduced in 
Mission 3)?! WHAT IS THIS MADNESS!?

Funniest thing is that I could legitimately argue that EDF2017 was the best 
example of Games as Art I have ever seen due to the fact that it tells an 
experience rather than a story and delivers something that CANNOT be done 
in a movie.

Because we've SEEN EDF The Movie, it's EVERY CHEESY SCI-FI MOVIE EVER 
except rather than watching the Japanese Military get stepped on by 
Godzilla, we ARE the nameless, faceless troopers taking on Godzilla with a 
rocket launcher. We are NOT the heroes, we are not special, we do not have 
a backstory or a name, the ONLY thing that makes us special is the fact 
that WE'RE playing this character and the game DRIVES HOME the fact that 
you are weak and drastically outmatched as it flings you around. The fact 
that you can LOSE emphasizes this fact.

The result is that it takes cheesy sci-fi we used to laugh at and flips the 
perspective. Sort of a "What if this was real? What if there really WERE 
giant ants that weren't just ants filmed really close to the camera? What 
if YOU had to fight them? Yeah, then what?". This absolutely CANNOT be done 
in a movie because movies need a real protagonist with backstory and above 
all they aren't YOU.

Chances are I put more thought into this argument than the developers did 
on the game, and THAT is wonderful. (and yes I did specify 2017 due to 
slightly better writing/acting/story. The last mission seriously gives me 
goosebumps every time. 2025 is otherwise superior in every way.)
comments.author: GELTONZ

comments.text:
+Aegix Drakan Not much undead, but in a way everything in this world is 
undead or dying. The way they handle it is that everything is near death, 
being drained out spiritually until they become devoid of faculty and 
emotion.  In essence, your greatest enemy is this kind of loneliness and 
desperation the environment conveys through not only the monolithic 
architecture, but also every AI coming to hunt you. There's a part in game 
where you have to find a book for kindling fires (for reasons, but no I 
don't want to spoil why it is).  You enter an area with multiple bodies 
piled outside with disfigured facial masks, contorted, incomplete, and hung 
on crosses.  When you finally find the boss and enter through the doorway, 
it seems to not expect you (coincidentally it's also the weakest enemy in 
game).  It's a pathetic little thing called Pinwheel.  After killing it, 
you discover from the descriptions of three masks that Pinwheel had were 
named "Mask of the Father", "Mask of the Mother", and "Mask of the Child."

Each description tells a different part of the same story. 

"One of the three masks of the Pinwheel, the necromancer who stole the 
power of the Gravelord, and reigns over the Catacombs.
This mask, belonging to the valiant father, slightly raises equipment load."
- Mask of the Father.

"One of the three masks of the Pinwheel, the necromancer who stole the 
power of the Gravelord, and reigns over the Catacombs.
This mask, belonging to the kindly mother, slightly raises HP."
- Mask of the Mother.

"One of the three masks of the Pinwheel, the necromancer who stole the 
power of the Gravelord, and reigns over the Catacombs."
"This mask, belonging to the naive child, slightly raises stamina recovery 
speed."
- Mask of the Child.

In the room, you see various books Pinwheel has been reading and Pinwheel 
himself looks like a conglomerate of different entities.  

Basically, most players believe that with this evidence given by the 
developers, you killed this creature's one chance of maybe restoring the 
three different entities, the mother, the father, and the child by taking 
the Rite of Kindling, a book stolen by the abomination that may have had 
secrets in reversing this curse.  There was also more lore supporting this 
conclusion, but I'm blanking on it.  In your attempt to gain power, you 
slay this beast that you only later find out what it was.  

This is only one battle.  Tons of more bosses tell their own story like 
this. Without even a single word exposited to the player through excessive 
dialogue trees. 

Also now that I think of it, L.A. Noire was also a fucking great 
investigation game that was also a triple a title. 

Sorry for the long story, if you made it to this part of the convo, take a 
look at some lore videos or gameplay videos if this game has piqued your 
interest.
comments.author: GothaBillsAndDeath

comments.text:
+UpNorthGameReviews Silent Hill, Thief, and Oldboy (the original movie) 
have cult followings, does that mean you trust the integrity of the game or 
the community when rating a game solely on it's merits alone?  

> Abysmal story, abysmal lore, difficulty is all over the map,

How? Explain?

> enemy AI is erratic

You mean they stand in place until their detection spots the player? 
 Erratic as in how?

> horrible hit detection, bad hit boxes

Again, explain this as a giant sword has the range of a truck and hits slow 
while claws hits fast and short in range.  I can understand lagstabs and 
whatnot being a menace on the pvp end though.

> horrible voice acting,

Most of the game was silent.  That's like saying Silent Hill 2's rape 
monsters had horrible voice acting.  The implementation of sound or 
interaction with AI capable of dialogue were sparse in both in order to 
drive home the game's atmosphere and mood.

> you're too stupid to walk and drink a flask at the same time.

So you want to constantly heal and move when the game's sole purpose is to 
make you decide what time it's appropriate to do either? This is 
considerably minor considering the vast majority of the game would be 
broken if you could do that at the sametime.  Healing shouldn't be easy to 
perform if the game consists of survival.  And no I do not mean 
mechanically as in the designers didn't repair it's glitches.  To put it 
simply, why should I refill myself with easy health packs in Duke Nukem if 
that nullifies the fun of the game's survival aspect forcing me to take new 
hallways and conserve health. Imagine how long any pvp would last if every 
character could heal like that. 

> Tough shit, you need to reload before you're allowed to move again.

Now your deliberately bashing.  Reload takes less than a second especially 
when you switch weapons.  

> Well you see asshole your class of sword can't do that because reasons.

... because each move has their own ability set like a Tekken wet dream. 
 It's called making weapons unique.  With a rapier I can parry attacks 
easier, a broadsword that doesn't stab sweeps enemies infront making it so 
faster attacking enemies using primarily low range melee weapons, 
specialized daggers have swift and swirling animations that tactically hide 
their potential chance of hitting in battle dances in order to feel fluent 
and deadly.  

> But if for some crazy reason you need to play it, tell me what platform.

If for some crazy reason people want to check out how the developers 
actually spent time making a game in commentary that never leans on the 
pretentious bullshit dragon age 2 did with mash the A button, then you can 
find it on Youtube and rate for yourself. 

tl;dr: Everything you said was wrong from not only a subjective standpoint, 
but a technical one.
comments.author: GothaBillsAndDeath

comments.text:
I'd recommend just skipping Dark Souls. It's fanbase is what we call a 
"cult following", and you would never trust a cult, would you? Abysmal 
story, abysmal lore, difficulty is all over the map, enemy AI is erratic, 
and plain stupid, horrible hit detection, bad hit boxes, one of the worst 
online systems to ever be put into a game, horrible voice acting, sound 
track is so so (bad and good tunes in it), and it suffers from a shit storm 
of basic design flaws. Want to heal? Stand still, you're too stupid to walk 
and drink a flask at the same time. Want to fire a crossbow and run? Tough 
shit, you need to reload before you're allowed to move again. want to 
thrust your sword? Well you see asshole your class of sword can't do that 
because reasons. It's a bad game, everyone should avoid it. 

But if for some crazy reason you need to play it, tell me what platform. If 
you have it on PC I think I deleted my save files, but I do have gear on a 
Xbox 360 save file if you want it.
comments.author: UpNorthGameReviews

comments.text:
Infamous also has a plot it takes way too seriously for its own good, the 
enemies are less batshit insane, the weapons aren't as crazy, and they try 
to sell you as a superhero (or brooding villain, they give you a moral 
choice system) rather than just another soldier who by all rights shouldn't 
last two seconds in the battle. Infamous is a great series, and I do 
legitimatley think it's fun, but it's not the same as this, mostly because 
it has less focus on its own over-top-insanity.

comments.text:

mostly with the opinions stated in your Colonial Marines, Red Dead

could actually be this insulting to your viewers. I know that opinions 
stated in these videos are done via hyperbole and I know that is part of 
your charm, sometimes I find it grating and sometimes I find it funny but 
there are others, including both your fans and detractors that take your 
opinions, including the hyperbole seriously and as fact.

captions.text:
Hey, gang! You remember 'fun', right?
"You seem very jolly, Basil."

"Hmm?"
"You seem very jolly."

"Jolly?"
"Yes, jolly. Sort of... happy."

"Oh, 'happy'. Yes, I remember that. No, not
that I've noticed, dear, no. I'll report it

if it happens, though."
Sure you do! You know! It's that thing triple-A

releases haven't been since 2007! The thing
that causes Yahtzee to break out in hives

in or around the same bodily orifice that
generates his opinions. And perhaps no modern

title since 2010's middle-market sleeper 'Deadly
Premonition' better exemplifies this long-dormant

antiquated attribute from gaming's bygone
glory... in all its unrepentant, batshit splendor...

than Earth Defense Force 2025!
Sure, at first glance, it's a small-market

third-person shooting explosion-fest with
a budget roughly the size of a dust mite's

dick on a cold day. But at second glance...?
Well, that's exactly what it is! And that's

fuckin' awesome!
Yet to describe this game as a 'shooter' is

to do it a measurable disservice. For one
thing, in a practical sense, many of the game's

weapons do not 'shoot' anything at all, unless
of course 'vagina-throttling unbridled badassery'

counts as a fucking projectile.
In a wholesale inversion of modern game developer

logic, EDF2025 - like each of the 5 games
that preceded it in this series - is a game

defined, not by what untoward, jaggy bits
it's shorn from the core formula to placate

a double-wide audience that no longer fucking
exists. It's a game defined by what's been

added to the formula, coupled with the series'
trademark incomparable motherfuckin' lunacy!

This game is ri-goddamn-diculous in the best
possible regard! The literal embodiment of

everything great about Japanese video games...
and the antithesis of their latter-day downfalls.

What's that? Kojima's releasing Metal Gear
Solid 5? For 60 dollars? And it's 30 seconds

long? Here. Have 85 fucking missions in your
Earth Defense Force 2025 campaign! For $50!

I've said it before, and I'll say it again:
"I do the cha-cha... like a sissy girl."

Japanese games don't suck!
Hideo Kojima, Motomu Toriyama, and Kaz - fucking

- Hirai suck! And the games they produce,
and/or fund, and/or sign the fuck off on suck,

by association! Fact!
Like every Earth Defense Force title before

it, it's a case of excess... having a three-way
with bombast and decadence. Why?

Yngwie Malmsteen will now explain precisely
why:

"You know. Remember: 'Less is more'. And I
always said... how can that be? How can LESS

be MORE? It's impossible. MORE is more."
You're A-1 fuckin' right, Maestro. Now for

the love of all that's holy, apply that principal
to filling your bath tub with salon conditioner...

and dive the fuck in head-first. It looks
like you thumb-wrestled with a motherfucking

light socket, chief.
BioWare! Eidos! Bethesda! IO Interactive!

Blizzard! Square Enix! Every developer that
has ever removed a third of the original game,

added two new gimmicky mechanics and had the
monolithic, heaving rhino balls to call it

a motherfucking 'sequel'!
LEND ME YOUR FUCKING EARS!

Less. Is not. MORE!
MORE... is more!

Enjoyed having one soldier class in Earth
Defense Force 2017?

Badass! Here's four more! Liked the weapon
variety in earlier titles? Here. You're a

walking fuckin' armory. Go with God! And don't
forget your weapons level the fuck UP with

you!
...and speaking of weapons, do you recall

in my Rageaholic Movie Review of the 1985
Chuck Norris classic 'Invasion U.S.A.', when

I opined... the following?
"Let me tell you something, Infinity Ward:

If you make an FPS out of THIS instead of
another modern military game that invents

new shades of brown... I'll buy fifty fuckin'
copies. Especially if I get to play as Chuck

Norris and wield a gun that shoots FISTS!"
Well wish. Fucking. GRANTED!

Not only does this game feature the use of
a cybernetic motherfuckin' piston-fist large

enough to crack Jupiter open like a goddamn
walnut... it also happens to be easily one

of the most potent items of weaponry in this
entire ever-lovin' game!

I say let turbo-wimps like the Ranger and
the Air Raider have their Assault Rifles and

lazer crossbows. Because when you find yourself
in an impromptu game of rock-'em-sock'-em

robots with the Iron fucking Giant at 1/1,000th
scale, literally punching enemy fighter craft

from orbit, you'll be far too preoccupied
with nursing an erection so throbbing large

it interferes with local cellphone reception
to remotely give a fuck!

And while the graphics are a brand of 'ugly'
more commonly reserved for members of the

English Royal Family... they are nevertheless
a significant upgrade from previous titles

in the series. Whereas Earth Defense Force
2017 looks like a goddamn PS2 game... EDF

2025...? Could easily be mistaken for a late-year
original Xbox title. So yeah. Have a gold

star.
Which isn't, of course, to say that EDF2025

is technically unimpressive. Fuzzy textures
or fuckin' no, witnessing literally hundreds

of swarming enemies of every conceivable configuration
swirling and reeling above your head with

only the occasional dip in framerate... really
sledgehammers the fuck home the immutable

fact that - if Triple-A developers are indeed
being 'held back' - it's certainly not by

7th-gen hardware! We live in a world where
developers manufacture excuses daily... and

actual games once every 4 years if everything
goes right. I can't imagine why software sales

are down over 20%. Pull up a seat beside the
Mad Hatter and the Cheshire Cat, because we

have officially arrived on the other side
of the developmental looking glass, rageaholics!

But the unifying principle of the entire EDF
series, at last polished and harnessed into

a blustery tornado of building-sized arthropods,
kaiju robots and flying bitches in stainless

steel bikini-bottoms... is the same principle
that began this very review.

FUN.
Earth Defense Force 2025... especially when

played cooperatively with a friend... is mind-blowingly
fuckin' FUN. A trait modern games are generating

in exponentially diminished supply, these
days. So lap it the fuck up while you can,

rageaholics.
I'm RazörFist.
God - fuckin' - SPEED!

title: Earth Defense Force 2025 Review - The Rageaholic
